title: 108_hr898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lumbee Recognition Act". The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to acknowledge the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes and deserving of full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe. The Lumbee Indians are now entitled to full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe, with all benefits, privileges, and immunities that come with this status. The Lumbee Indians are entitled to full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to extend federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, allowing them to receive benefits and services provided to federally recognized tribes. Other Indian groups in specific counties can petition for tribal acknowledgement. Members residing in certain counties are considered to be living near an Indian reservation. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is granted federal recognition, allowing them to access services and benefits provided to federally recognized tribes. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Health and Human Services will develop a budget for services eligible to tribe members upon verification of a tribal roll. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is granted federal recognition, allowing access to services and benefits for tribe members. The tribal roll will define the service population, with lands in Robeson County treated as trust acquisitions. North Carolina will have jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on tribal lands. North Carolina will have jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on tribal lands, with the possibility of transferring jurisdiction to the United States after consulting with the Attorney General.
